docs.text:
Welcome to EduBlocks Documentation Page


This page is not to host resources, but is purely for command reference for each of the libraries.


On the left hand side you can see a menu bar, click on each of the different library names to read
up on what it does and what commands you can use.


It will also give you a description of the product and a pinout guide if it is an add-on board.


For any enquiries please send an email to: 
support@edublocks.org
docs.title: Welcome to EduBlocks Documentation Page

docs.text:
This page is not to host resources, but is purely for command reference for each of the libraries.  On the left hand side you can see a menu bar, click on each of the different library names to read
up on what it does and what commands you can use.  It will also give you a description of the product and a pinout guide if it is an add-on board.  For any enquiries please send an email to:  support@edublocks.org
docs.title: Welcome to EduBlocks Documentation Page

docs.text:
What is Minecraft Pi Edition?


Minecraft Pi Edition is a version of Minecraft developed for the Raspberry Pi. It is based on an old version of Pocket Edition but is slightly cut down, containing a revised feature set and support for multiple programming languages. EduBlocks has a feature that includes the Minecraft Python Library to interact with the Minecraft world.


Starting Minecraft Pi Edition


Minecraft Pi can easily be started from the Raspberry Pi Menu. Simply click on the Raspberry Pi logo in the
top left hand corner of your Raspberry Pi desktop and navigate to Games and click on Minecraft Pi. 


This may not work on your VNC Servers! We recommend using a standard HDMI setup.



Command Reference


The below commands are those that can be found in EduBlocks. The block will be shown, and below it will be the Python code and then a breif description.


1. Import Minecraft




Python Code:


from mcpi.minecraft import Minecraft




Usage:
This command imports the Minecraft API for us to interact with Minecraft via Python & EduBlocks


2. MCPI Block Import




Python Code:


from mcpi import block




Usage:
This command allows us to reference to the Minecraft Blocks via their names rather than the numbered id's
